body: @theofidry Looks like PHP-Scoper gets confused by https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/phpunit/blob/30dd6bfd0f45a4804096b13845a85a3c388d549c/src/Framework/TestCase.php#L29 followed by https://github.com/sebastianbergmann/phpunit/blob/30dd6bfd0f45a4804096b13845a85a3c388d549c/src/Framework/TestCase.php#L117
@sebastianbergmann what that confusion results in exactly?

```
abstract class TestCase extends Assert implements Reorderable, SelfDescribing, Test
```
is transformed to
```
abstract class TestCase extends \PHPUnit\assert implements \PHPUnit\Framework\Reorderable, \PHPUnit\Framework\SelfDescribing, \PHPUnit\Framework\Test
```
and `\PHPUnit\assert` is not a class but a function.
I am beginning to wonder how the original, unscoped code works in the first place.

I'd argue that the original PHP Code that PHP-Scoper is falling over is broken.

Class- and function names are case-insenstive. The original code shouldn't even work.

> The original code shouldn't even work.

And yet it does ðŸ˜ƒ Maybe @nikic can shine a light on this?

That is interesting... It's worth mentioning that PHP-Scoper does not respects PHP's case insensitiveness (see https://github.com/humbug/php-scoper/issues/393). I would be interested in hearing more on how this works out on PHP side and determine if it's something that should be addressed in PHP-Scoper, a case that although not be supported but PHP-Scoper could fail in a meaningful way on or something to ignore completely
@sebastianbergmann I don't see what's supposed to be wrong with that code?
@theseer Functions and classes do not share the same symbol space. You can have a function, a class and a constant with the same name.

> Functions and classes do not share the same symbol space.

Thank you, Nikita.
